t: Job 40
The*p Lord*s answered Job:
Will*pn the one who contends with the Almighty correct him? Let*ln him who argues with God give an answer.
Then*p Job answered the Lord:*s
I*pn am so insignificant. How can I answer you? I*ln place my hand over my mouth.
I*ln have spoken once, and I will not reply; twice,*ln but now I can add nothing.
Then*p the Lord*s answered Job from the whirlwind:
Get*pn ready to answer me like a man; When*ln I question you, you will inform me.
Would*ln you really challenge my justice? Would*ln you declare me guilty to justify yourself?
Do*ln you have an arm like God’s? Can*ln you thunder with a voice like his?
Adorn*pn yourself with majesty and splendor, and*ln clothe yourself with honor and glory.
Pour*ln out your raging anger; look*ln on every proud person and humiliate him.
Look*ln on every proud person and humble him; trample*ln the wicked where they stand.
Hide*ln them together in the dust; imprison*ln them in the grave.
Then*ln I will confess to you that*ln your own right hand can deliver you.
Look*pn at Behemoth, which*ln I made along with you. He*ln eats grass like cattle.
Look*ln at the strength of his back and*ln the power in the muscles of his belly.
He*ln stiffens his tail like a cedar tree; the*ln tendons of his thighs are woven firmly together.
His*ln bones are bronze tubes; his*ln limbs are like iron rods.
He*ln is the foremost of God’s works; only*ln his Maker can draw the sword against him.
The*ln hills yield food for him, while*ln all sorts of wild animals play there.
He*ln lies under the lotus plants, hiding*ln in the protection of marshy reeds.
Lotus*ln plants cover him with their shade; the*ln willows by the brook surround him.
Though*ln the river rages, Behemoth is unafraid; he*ln remains confident, even if the Jordan surges up to his mouth.
Can*ln anyone capture him while he looks on, or*ln pierce his nose with snares?
